intro: Plagiogyria articulata, commonly known as the creeping redweed, is a flowering plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It is a member of the Polygonaceae family, characterized by its distinctive arrow-shaped leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, disturbed soils along stream banks and in wet meadows. Its stems are prostrate and often root at the nodes, allowing it to spread vegetatively. Plagiogyria articulata is valued for its ecological role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various invertebrates.
